NoteLiteral.En: Video zoom link will shared after admission process is completed.

Description.En: The course begins by providing a broad motivation for the design of multi- and many-core processors such as graphics processing units (GPUs). The first phase covers basic GPU concepts, including the evolution of GPU computing, a high-level overview of GPU architecture, and key differences from CPU architecture. Supplementary material is provided for students without a background in computer architecture fundamentals. Once a basic understanding is established, the module introduces the programming of GPUs using CUDA. The curriculum then delves into advanced concepts from both an architectural and programming perspective. To reinforce the theoretical knowledge gained in the lectures, students will engage in progressively more complex exercises throughout the module.

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course learners will be equiped with the skills necessary for effective GPU programming and be able to do programming.

Title.En: Solve computationally intensive tasks faster and with lower energy consumption

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course learners will be able to solve computationally intensive tasks faster and with lower energy consumption.

Title.En: Understanding of the architecture of massively parallel GPUs

NoteLiteral.En: At the end of the course learners will gained a comprehensive understanding of the underlying architecture of massively parallel Graphics Processing Units (GPUs).

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
There will be weekly lectures **every  thursday 11.15 am - 1 pm (CET**) . The course will mainly take a hybrid format by using a 360° conference camera which affords an immersive meeting experience for students on-site (from TUHH) and abroad.

To achieve the three intended goals in addition to in-class instruction, students will be presented with engaging take-home programming exercises designed to complement their learning experience. These exercises are intended to be tackled asynchronously and in small teams, fostering collaborative problem-solving. Each exercise is structured to span 3-4 weeks, constituting a dedicated self-learning phase. To ensure continual support and synchronization of progress, regular online meetings will be scheduled every 3-4 weeks, during which students can receive assistance and guidance as needed. This multifaceted approach aims to reinforce theoretical concepts, enhance practical skills, and promote collaborative learning throughout the course.
Providing you with hands-on experience in solving computationally intensive tasks faster and with lower energy consumption (SoSe25)

The course begins by providing a broad motivation for the design of multi- and many-core processors such as graphics processing units (GPUs). The first phase covers basic GPU concepts, including the evolution of GPU computing, a high-level overview of GPU architecture, and key differences from CPU architecture. Supplementary material is provided for students without a background in computer architecture fundamentals. Once a basic understanding is established, the module introduces the programming of GPUs using CUDA. The curriculum then delves into advanced concepts from both an architectural and programming perspective. To reinforce the theoretical knowledge gained in the lectures, students will engage in progressively more complex exercises throughout the module.

We particularly encourage students with a background in engineering and/or business to apply, but we welcome all other disciplines as well. Please be aware that initial programming knowledge is desirable for participation.

To apply, please send your CV and your transcript of records and make sure, all your documents are in English.

All students who pass will receive a certificate (Microcredential) from ECIU.
